The automatic stationkeeping system on LES-6 used an accurate onboard clock to provide an indication of the time at which the satellite should arrive at a given point in its orbit (2 1 ) ( 2 8 ) . The time of actual arrival, as determined by the clock and the coincidence of sun and earth sensor observations, was compared with the desired time to generate longitude position errors to be corrected by firing thrusters as appropriate. Thrusters firings were-activated at satellite orbital points separated by 1800 in order to ensure that orbit eccentricity remained constant.
